Moods are different from the simple emotions that\nare less specific, less intense and less likely to be caused and the induced by\na specific stimulus or event. For example, anger as an emotion usually has a\nspecific source, while irritability mood is less determined by the particular\ncause or source. <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-m_SvP31uuEE/WOUzPDaBWjI/AAAAAAABSHw/9fukQLOIRq8EAlwBy9XugHt-fWIuIrVSACLcB/s1600/immage0.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"326\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-m_SvP31uuEE/WOUzPDaBWjI/AAAAAAABSHw/9fukQLOIRq8EAlwBy9XugHt-fWIuIrVSACLcB/s640/immage0.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Moods have a positive\nor negative valence. They differ from temperament or personality traits, which\nare naturally more durable. At the same time, some personal characteristics\nsuch as optimism and neuroticism predispose certain types of moods. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Temperament on the\nother hand is a combination of stable individual psychological characteristics,\ndetermining the dynamics of the psychic activity of man and remaining\nrelatively constant at different motives, content and objectives of the\nactivity. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Emotion is associated\nwith a number of psychological phenomena, including temperament, personality,\nmood and motivation. Emotions are either signaled, for example, through the\nvoice and facial expressions or may be expressed by certain physiological\nreactions or behaviors. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The eight basic\nemotions are joy, fear, anger, grief, love, disgust, surprise and contempt. In\naddition to the basic emotions there are complex categories in which certain\nemotions are combined to form complex emotions. One model involves complex\nemotions arising from the basic emotions, influenced by cultural conventions or\nassociations. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Theree are also\nmeta-emotions - organized and structured set of emotions and cognitions about\nemotions, including both the individual's own emotions and the emotions of\nothers. The concept of meta-emotions reflects the idea that every time you\ngenerate a certain emotion it stirs subsequent emotions associated with the way\nin which the primary emotion is experienced.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Emotion is a complex\npsychological condition that includes three main components: subjective\nexperience, physiological reactions and behavioral responses<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again, Natyashastra\nsays&nbsp; that sattvikabhinaya is the most\nimportant mode of expression.&nbsp; A play\nis&nbsp; supreme if it contains\nsattvikabhinaya, of medium quality if it contains it to some extent and of low\nquality if satvikabhinaya is at all absent.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">To enact sattvikabhava\non stage the actor should be in state of high concentration, becoming mentally\nengaged in the extreme emotion situation, to experience it to such an extent,\nthat it cause his temper to manifest accordingly by specific physiological\nreactions.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: white;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white;\">This is the reason why\nin Kathakali the dancer does NOT speak. He does not follow the music, the music\nfollows him. &nbsp; Kathakali hence cannot have music from tape recorders</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A Tala&nbsp; literally means a \"clap, tapping one's\nhand on one's arm, a musical measure\" It is the term used in Indian\nclassical music to refer to musical meter that is any rhythmic beat or strike\nthat measures musical time<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The measure is\ntypically established by hand clapping, waving, touching fingers on thigh or\nthe other hand, verbally, striking of small cymbals, or a percussion instrument<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Along with raga which\nforms the fabric of a melodic structure, the tala forms the time cycle and\nthereby constitutes one of the two foundational elements of Kathakali<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A tala in Indian music\ncovers \"the whole subject of musical meter\". Indian music is composed\nand performed in a metrical framework, a structure of beats that is a tala. The\ntala forms the metrical structure that repeats, in a cyclical harmony, from the\nstart to end of any particular song or dance segment,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A tala measures musical\ntime in Indian music. However, it does not imply a regular repeating accent\npattern, instead its hierarchical arrangement depends on how the musical piece\nis supposed to performed.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A metric cycle\nof a tala contains a specific number of beats, which can be as short as 3 beats\nor as long as 128 beats.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The pattern repeats, but the play of accent and empty\nbeats are an integral part of Indian music architecture. Each tala has\nsubunits. In other words, the larger cyclic tala pattern has embedded smaller\ncyclic patterns, and both of these rhythmic patterns provide the musician and\nthe audience to experience the play of harmonious and discordant patterns at\ntwo planes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A musician can choose to intentionally challenge a pattern at the\nsubunit level by contradicting the tala, explore the pattern in exciting ways,\nthen bring the music and audience experience back to the fundamental pattern of\ncyclical beats.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The tala as the time\ncycle, and the raga as the melodic framework, are the two foundational elements\nof classical Indian music. The raga gives an artist the ingredients palette to\nbuild the melody from sounds, while the tala provides her with a creative\nframework for rhythmic improvisation using time.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vedas and the\nNatyashastra were transmitted orally for 330 centuries before being penned down\n70 centuries ago. Not a syllable of tome was missed, . This is the greatest\nfeat of man.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The need to develop\nmathematically precise musical meters is&nbsp;\ndriven by the Indian use of oral tradition for transmitting vast amounts\nof Vedic literature.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Deeply and systematically embedded structure and\nmeters&nbsp; have enabled the ancient Indians\na means to detect and correct any errors of memory or oral transmission from\none person or generation to the next.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Samaveda&nbsp; included a system of chironomy, or hand\nsignals to set the recital speed. These were mudras (finger and palm postures)\nand jatis (finger counts of the beat), a system at the foundation of talas.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The chants in the Vedic recital text, associated with rituals, are presented to\nbe measured in matras and its multiples in the invariant ratio of 1:2:3. This\nsystem is also the basis of every tala<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">the idiophone in the\nform of \"small bronze cymbals\" were used for tala. Almost the entire\nchapter of Natyashastra on idiophones,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Each tala is divided in\ntwo ways to perfect the musical performance, one is called kala (kind) and the\nother gati (pulse). A tala does not have a fixed tempo (laya) and can be played\nat different speeds<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The basic structure of\nthe music in Kerala is really unique and it has even contributed few ragas\nwhich are only seen in the ritual music of the state. <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/id3IfkSNTDg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/id3IfkSNTDg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tyanis are short songs\nsung standing on the Sopana of a temple with the accompaniment of Idaikka. This\nis called Kottipadi seva or in general term Sopana Sangitha. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are many Dhyana\nSlokas in Sanskrit associated to different Devi and Devas. The songs composed\nin the style of these Dhyana Slokas in Malayalam came to be called as Tyanis.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Dhyana Slokas in Sanskrit are composed in accordance to the Tantric\nrituals. So Tyanis were composed in place of these Dhyana Slokas so as to sing\nto the accompaniment of ritualistic accompaniments.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Tyanis are composed in four couplets. There\nare Tyanis in praise of each and every important deities worshipped in the\ntemples of Kerala. Tyanis usually don\u2019t have the sections like Pallavi,\nAnupallavi and Charanam. From the lyrics of Tyanis one can make out to which\nplace does the temple belong.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Also there are tyanis for different&nbsp; manifestations of the deity, for instance,\nthere are separate Tyanis for Vishnu, Padmanabha, and Krishna eventhough they\nare one. There are Tyanis based on the origin of the temple and also about the\npeculiarities of the presiding deity of the temple.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Tyanis are usually composed in ragas. There\nare certain ragas prescribed for singing the Tyanis known as Nidana ragas. Time\nfor singing these ragas are strictly followed. There are specific ragas for\nTyanis that is to be sung for various Poojas. The main ragas in which the\nTyanis are sung are Desakshi, Srikanti, Nalattha, Malahari, Ahiri, Bhupali,\nSamantha Malahari, Natta, Andhari, Puraniru and Andhali.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/wDChBKn7W7Y/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/wDChBKn7W7Y?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Kerala\u2019s greatest\ncontribution to the world of music is its intricate and complex talas and of\ncourse tala Vadyas. . Thus talas of Kerala can be classified into;---<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A] Those used in the\ntemple rituals of Kerala<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">B] Those figuring in\nthe ensembles performed during temple festivals or Utsavas of Kerala.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">C] Those employed in\nthe music that accompanies the dance and traditional theatrical performances.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Kshethra talas or talas\nused in the temple rituals of Kerala.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In each temple, for\neach ritual specific talas are prescribed to be played on a group of\ninstruments such as Idakka, Timila , Maddalam, Maram, Chenda Ilathalam etc.\nthis is a very old tradition and still followed with great devotion and\nausterity<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/mTjO_XTx_bU/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/mTjO_XTx_bU?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are talas\nspecified for each deities, Balipeetas, corners, places and Pradakshinas. Some\ntalas are also found prescribed for more than one deity and occasion. There are\nabout 11 such talas followed in temple rituals.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ekam--The old name for\nthis tala is Ekaputam. It consists of one Anga and one Matra.ie.4 aksharakalas.\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Randam talam--- Randam\ntalam consists of one Laghu and Guru, thus total Matras 3 ie.12 aksharakalas, <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Moonnaam talam--- This\ntalam consists of Plutam, Guru and Guru, total Matras being 7, 28\naksharakalas..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nalaam talam--- Nalaam\ntalam has 8 Matras, 32 aksharakalas and its constituent Angas are Plutam,\nLaghu, Guru and Guru. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Anchaam talam--- This\nconsists of Plutam, Laghu, Laghu, Guru and Guru, so total Matras 9 ie.36\naksharakalas . Among these the first Anga Laghu is silent. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sambhu talam---- Sambhu\ntalam of 3 Matras,12 aksharakalas, is used in the third Purapradakshinam. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mangala talam--- This\nprominent talam consists of Guru, Laghu and Laghu comprising 4 Matras,16\naksharakalas. It is played for Digbali at the north-east corner. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sakatu talam---- Sakatu\ntalam consists of Laghu, Laghu and Guru of 4 Matras,16 aksharakalas . It is\nused in the outer Pradakshinam. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mutakku talam---&nbsp; The Angas of Mutakku talam are Guru, Laghu\nand Guru, Matras will be five. So aksharakalas will be Twenty. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Takatu talam--- Takatu\ntalam is 9 Matras,36 aksharakalas. Its constituent Angas are Plutam, Laghu,\nLaghu, Guru and Guru. In this talam also first Laghu is silent. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Kaarika talam---\nKaarika talam consists of the Angas Laghu, Laghu, Laghu and guru of 5 Matras ie\n20 aksharakalas. This is played during Digbalis at four main quarters.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Shatkalam or playing in\n6 speeds is a common feature followed in Kerala ensembles. The starting tempo\nof a Melom will be Pati Kalam-Ati Ati Vilamba Kalam having duration of 32\nAkshara Kalas.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/fLOXOaXUcDo/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/fLOXOaXUcDo?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are artists who\ncan easily play all the 6 Kalas.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While performing a Tayampaka or Chenta Melom\nthe exact doubling of the tempo is not followed. Here gradual progression of\nthe tempo is followed. The speed variations are done to show the skill of the\nplayers and to overcome monotony.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/GlMFdcN61qg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/GlMFdcN61qg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;In Kathakali&nbsp;\ngenerally five main varieties of talas are used. They consist of&nbsp; eight, ten, fourteen, seven or six intervals.\nThe following are the&nbsp; chief and popular\ntalas used therein : ---<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">1 Kalah kriya\nparichinna tala shabdeh na bhadyateh. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Adi or Chempata, Champa\nor Jumpa, Atanta or Ata. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tripata or Muriatanta,\nand Panchari or Roopaka. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Their swaroop or\ndescription is as follows : --<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Adi : consists of eight\nintervals. It has three beats and two waves (i.e., leaves). This whole in\nWestern terminology may be said as eight crotchets in three bars. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Champta : has 10\nintervals with three beats and one let off. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is quavers in\nthree bars. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The tala with 14\nintervals and four strokes and two leaves is termed as Atanta. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tripata consists of\nseven intervals with stroke divisions on the first, fourth, and sixth and\nleaves on the fifth and seventh. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Panchari tala has six\nintervals. Beats fall on the first and fifth interval, while the leave is given\non the sixth interval<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/B-nSzrKGMX0/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/B-nSzrKGMX0?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\nKathakali has seven items to act upon. They are:<o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n1 Todayam (basic dance)<o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n2 Purappadu (debut of the main character)<o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n3 Tiranokku (curtain look by evil characters or demons)<o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n4 Kummi (preamble for the female character\u2019s appearance)<o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n5 Kathakali (the main play)<o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n6 Kalaasam (passage of hyped dance as hyphen between two\npieces of verse play)</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n7 Samaapanam (concluding benediction dance)<o:p></o:p></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Below: Thodayam ( behind curtain )</span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/p_i1yz35Frs/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/p_i1yz35Frs?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Below- Purappadu&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/dyD85PaxPjQ/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/dyD85PaxPjQ?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Below: Kummi-- a<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;preamble of\nfemale characters appearance. In Kummithe movements and\ngestures are not rigid. Gentleness and mildness with slow paces are Kummi\u2019s\nspecialties.</span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/5eXx21Foicc/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/5eXx21Foicc?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Below: Thiranokku by the evil character</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/QXr7KkCozfU/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/QXr7KkCozfU?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Below- Kalasam -interlude , a deliberate break of narrative, an alienation method to break the audience out of their spell and become aware of themselves-- this is pure nritta /dance ( not acting ) in thandava style&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/2eWRzvs7GLk/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/2eWRzvs7GLk?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<b style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">TODAY TO SABOTAGE KATHAKALI FOREIGN FUNDED CHRISTIAN NGOs DRESS UP PRETENDERS , WHO WRIGGLE THEIR EYEBROWS , DO SOME MINDLESS FINGER MOVEMENTS , BANG THEIR LEGS &nbsp;-- ACCOMPANIED BY MUSIC FROM ELECTRONIC INSTRUMENTS&nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">ONCE YOU SEE THIS MINDLESS NONSENSE, &nbsp;YOU WILL NEVER GO FOR ANOTHER KATHAKALI RECITAL &nbsp; ..</span></b><br />\n<b><br /></b>\n<b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">GRACEFUL TALENTED MOHINIYATTAM DANCERS WERE CALLED TEMPLES WHORES BY THE WHITE MAN AND THIS DANCE WAS BANNED BY A GOVT ACT --&nbsp;</b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></b>\n<b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">BUT HEY, MILEY RAY CYRUS, &nbsp;MADONNA, &nbsp;LADY GAGA AND THEIR ILK SHOWING THEIR TITS, &nbsp;TWATS AND UNWASHED ASSHOLE ON STAGE IS INGICREW ( IN THE GROOVE ) ?</b><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/07/kamasutra-by-vatsayana-immoral-sexual.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/07/kamasutra-by-vatsayana-immoral-sexual.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/02/devadasi-system-immoral-lie-of-temple.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/02/devadasi-system-immoral-lie-of-temple.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><b>SHIVA THE COSMIC DANCER , WAS BRANDED A SEXUAL PREDATOR AND A CORPSE EATER...&nbsp;</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><b>RIGHT NOW THERE IS ONE US CNN TV PRESENTER , AN IRANIAN JEW NAMED REZA ASLAN WHO IS DOING THIS PROPAGANDA. &nbsp; &nbsp;</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://rightlog.in/2017/03/reza-aslan-cnn-attack-hinduism-together/\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://rightlog.in/2017/03/reza-aslan-cnn-attack-hinduism-together/</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><b>IF I WERE MODI-- I WOULD BAN CNN FROM INDIA AND ARREST REZA AZLAN THE MOMENT HE COMES TO INDIA</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/09/aghoris-corpse-eaters-of-india-capt.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/09/aghoris-corpse-eaters-of-india-capt.html</a><o:p></o:p><br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: red;\"><b>TILL THE WHITE INVADER CAME TO INDIA, WE NEVER HEARD OF\nAGHORIS.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: red;\"><b>INDIANS WERE VEGANS, LEAVE ALONE EATING DEAD HUMAN CORPSES\nOR THROWING MENSES BLOOD AND ANIMAL BLOOD ON THE IDOL OF THE GOD IN TEMPLES</b></span></span><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/11/all-animal-sacrifices-in-hindu-temples.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/11/all-animal-sacrifices-in-hindu-temples.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Sanskrit word\n\"bhAAva\" means \"emotion, sentiment, state of body or mind,\ndisposition\", while \"bhava\"&nbsp;\nmeans \"being, worldly existence, becoming, birth, be, production,\norigin\". <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The former term is\nrooted in latter, and in some context also means \"becoming, being,\nexisting, occurring, appearance\" while connoting the condition thereof.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u015b\u0101ntabh\u0101va, the calm,\npeaceful, gentle or saintly attitude<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">d\u0101syabh\u0101va, the\nattitude of devotion<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">sakhyabh\u0101va, the\nattitude of a friend<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">v\u0101tsalyabh\u0101va, the\nattitude of a mother towards her child<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">madhurabh\u0101va (or\nkantabhava), the attitude of a woman in love<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tanmayabhava, the\nattitude that the Lord is present everywhere<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The human body is made\nup of minute anatomical units which function individually or in combination\nwith other parts. The muscles play an important part in Kathakali and the\nmovements of the facial muscles are a most significant part of a dancer's\ntraining.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The geometrical pattern which the dancer follows may be described as\nRECTANGLE , with the dancer standing with book feet apart, knees turned out and\nthe outer soles of the feet touching the ground. This position may be\nidentified as the mandala sthana&nbsp; shown\non the THIRASHEELA .&nbsp; The dancer covers\nspace also in patterns of rectangles.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The right foot meets the left and one\nside of the rectangle. The dancer moves forward to the third corner of the\nrectangle and then back to the second corner and finally comes back to the\nfirst corner but only touching all four points. With his arms and hands, the\ndancer covers space usually in figures of rectangles or clearly drawn diagonals\nalong these rectangles.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Occasionally the hands execute figures of eight and the\neyes follow, but the movement sequence always limits imaginary geometric\npattern. The KNEES are always turned OUT and there is invariably space of two\nto three feet between the feet.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The torso is used as one unit or occasionally,\ntwo i.e. the upper and lower torso. Jumps, spirals, sweeps and leaps are\ncharacteristic. Leg extensions are clear and the weight must be shifted from\none foot to the other in these extensions with ease.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is an essential part of\nthe dancers training to learn how to use each facial muscle separately. The\nmovement of the eyebrows, the eyeballs and the lower eyelids described in\nNatyasastra are not used to such an extent in any other dance style of India.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the nritta portions\nof Kathakali, the dancer executes leg-extensions and jumps still covering space\nin a series of rectangles to a given time cycle (tala).&nbsp;&nbsp; The units of the nritta portions are the\nKalasams.&nbsp; In Kathakali these cadences of\ndance patterns culminate in compositions known as araddis which are usually\nmultiples of three.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Other types of nritta sequences, based on different ways of\nmanipulating the rhythm, are known as the adakams and the tomakarams. The pure\nnritta technique appears in the repertoire mostly as a prelude to the\ndance-dramas.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The todayam and the purappadu may be described as typical nritta\nnumbers. In both, the dancer begins the movement in the slow tempo of the basic\nmetrical cycle and then to the mnemonics of the mandalam and the chenda,\nexecutes the nritta patterns. The hand or arm gestures here are few and usually\nonly variations between the alapadma and the hamsasya.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The abhinaya technique\nof Kathakali has such variety and flexibility that it allows the dancer actor\nto treat his theme or his character in many ways apart from the possibility of\nimprovising or taking off on the sung words or dancing the words &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is always the possibility of some\ninterpolated passages through&nbsp; mime. Here\nthe Kathakali actor has the fullest freedom, he follows no text and he can\nimprovise to his heart's content. He follows NO beat, rather the follows\nhim.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is known as the manodharma of\nthe actor. He must keep to the basic character which he is portraying. He must\ncreate that dominant mood whether it is of love or humour, compassion or\ndisgust or tranquility. The play actor is king.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Kathakali actor uses\nthe hastas, i.e. the hands and the eyes as his most important instruments of\ncommunication never forgetting that these are used along with other micro\nmovements of the face and the micro movements of the lower lower limbs and the\ntorso.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Kathakali tradition of the hastas is different from that of the Natyasastra\nand the Abhinaya Darpana. The extended hand is called tripataka in the\nKathakali tradition.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The text followed by the Kathakali actor is the 'Hasta\nLakshana Dipika' which described 24 basic hastas of single hands and an equal\nnumber of combined hands. Each hasta can be used in its permutation and\ncombination with another hasta.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It can be used at different levels, it can be\nused along with the movements of the arms and the eyes delicately or with\nenergy or without. The Kathakali tradition has enlarged and elaborated the\nlanguage of gesture.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">SANATANA DHARMA IS\nROOTED IN SHABDA ( SOUND )-YET WE HAVE CONVERTED SOUND INTO GEOMETRY AT WILL\n.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\">THE EYE COULD SEE SOUND</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/04/kolam-designs-inaudible-mantras-vide.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/04/kolam-designs-inaudible-mantras-vide.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">THE SRI YANTRA IS A\nVISUAL REPRESENTATION OF HINDU KING MANTRA OM. &nbsp;THE EGYPTIAN PYRAMIDS BUILT BY AYYAPPA (\nIMHOTEP ) IS OM .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/12/108-numerical-equivalent-of-hindu-king.html\" style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"background-color: lime; font-size: large;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/12/108-numerical-equivalent-of-hindu-king.html</span></a><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>DUH ,</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>HOW CAN EGYPTIAN PYRAMIDS BE OM? &nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>BATAAO NAH ?</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>INDEED IT IS !</b></span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/10/eight-sided-pyramid-of-giza-egypt.html\"><span style=\"background-color: lime; font-size: large;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/10/eight-sided-pyramid-of-giza-egypt.html</span></a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The abhinaya is\npresented in three stages:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">a) word to word\nsynchronization (b) interpretation of the full line and (c) abhinaya of the\ndancer following the singer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is an aspect of\nabhinaya in Kathakali where the dancer uses the words of the line only as a\nstarting point and improvises a full sequence of movements. Hand-gestures\nlanguage is most significant here for the elaboration of the word. This\nposition, known as <b style=\"background-color: white;\">CHOLLIYATTAM</b> &nbsp;is the\nfinal test of any great dancer's imaginative faculties. Although the line of\npoetry may only say that Bhima went through a forest the dancer is at full\nliberty to present the forest in all its beauty and splendour.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b>THE ITALIAN WAITRESS WOULD HAVE KILLED THE GANGA AND KATHAKALI . &nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b>IT IS GOOD THAT SHE IS OUT OF POWER.</b></span><br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/iFvT0gaFu_4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/iFvT0gaFu_4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Abhinaya is seen in its\nmanifestations of the Vyabhichari or the Sancharibhava. Here the main objective\nof the Kathakali dancer is&nbsp; to evoke a\nparticular dominant mood (sthayibahva). This he does by presenting variations\non the same theme. In the abhinaya portions of Kathakali, the hastas assume\nprime importance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ashtakal asam, one\namong the Kalaasam, comprises of eight dance types in Kathakali performed to\nexpress the enormous joy of a character. The steps are composed in the \u2018Champa\u2019\nrhythm and require great mastery for an artiste to perform. Each performance\nends in Astakalaasam of huge movements, rhythm, orchestra, dance, music and\nmoods.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/TUuzvorbPjE/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/TUuzvorbPjE?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">Below: This may look like drama-- &nbsp; for Kalari is NOT a sport--</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">-- only one man will live to tell the story at the end of a fight--</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">--the real fight usually ends in seconds or couple of minutes .</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">In ancient days ALL repeat ALL &nbsp;Kathakali dancers were Kalari male experts .&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2011/12/kalaripayattu-oldest-and-deadliest.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2011/12/kalaripayattu-oldest-and-deadliest.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/eMAsCuDFSUI/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/eMAsCuDFSUI?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\">Below: This old Kerala woman got Padma award in 2017. &nbsp; &nbsp;One of Kerala's greatest URUMI experts was a beautiful woman named Unniyarcha -- today she is stuff of lore and ballads</span><br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\">Below: Kalari stretched the ligaments of Kathakali dancers at a young age</span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ZioVSjjC0Jg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZioVSjjC0Jg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">THE MAGIC OF KATHAKALI LIES IN THE SINGLE\nFLICKERING LIGHT SOURCE OF AN OIL LAMP, WITH LIGHT CASTING UPWARD SHADOWS ON THE ACTORS.&nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">&nbsp;THE AUDIENCE SITS IN DARKNESS. <o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></b></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">IF THIS IS TAKEN AWAY THE SHOW IS AESTHETICALLY DEAD\n.</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>There is NO other\ndanceform on this planet other than Kathakali which dishes out a generous\nvisual, audio and <span style=\"color: red;\">INTELLECTUAL </span>extravaganza<o:p></o:p></b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-SOQHMzZNXfs/WOZQ3-KTylI/AAAAAAABSJg/cRrQwspxXEg1RwHlk1KFeitv29Bu4kDyQCLcB/s1600/3-e14182099953662.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"486\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-SOQHMzZNXfs/WOZQ3-KTylI/AAAAAAABSJg/cRrQwspxXEg1RwHlk1KFeitv29Bu4kDyQCLcB/s640/3-e14182099953662.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><span style=\"color: red;\">Koodiyattam ( MUTHAPPAN THEYYAM ) , performed\nin North Kerala KAVU temples</span><span style=\"color: blue;\"> <b>predated Kathakali , much before Natya Shastra was\nconceived</b> </span><span style=\"color: red;\">--- this dance inspired the formation of Kathakali. </span></span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2012/10/muthappan-deity-of-north-kerala-capt.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2012/10/muthappan-deity-of-north-kerala-capt.html</a><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/RTTbvyIpSWo/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/RTTbvyIpSWo?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Koodiyattam used Mizhavu ( a large pot ) for\npercussion. <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Shiva\u2019s damaru ( knotted cords ) was played. Indeed\nin anient days there could be no Sopanam without Shiva\u2019s Damaru which beat\nSanskrit language and 54 alphabets into existence . &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-RxAtJGnMuaU/WOZRQMNn5nI/AAAAAAABSJk/7W8bydGWmzQgaJA9YQIfspOLxqm3cdqGACLcB/s1600/8289090a9f050me67e45b2a0412f5e696.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-RxAtJGnMuaU/WOZRQMNn5nI/AAAAAAABSJk/7W8bydGWmzQgaJA9YQIfspOLxqm3cdqGACLcB/s1600/8289090a9f050me67e45b2a0412f5e696.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Malayalam too has 54 alphabets. In Shiva\nShakti format is gives the magic number of 108<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">This is now modified to be Edakka played with\nrolls of single stick .<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Mz80Xw2-fM4/WOZRnniexrI/AAAAAAABSJo/WU2rpXBzlu42cwsHrBnVD-i6OTqYtzZegCLcB/s1600/theybgyam.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Large Elanthalam were mighty cymbals.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/9Ev7Y9zvlYw/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/9Ev7Y9zvlYw?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Shankh was blown ( related to Dhanwantari ,\nGod of Ayurveda who rose from the cosmic ocean after Samudramanthan )&nbsp; which is NOT done in Kathakali.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/03/secrets-of-shankh-or-conch-product-of.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/03/secrets-of-shankh-or-conch-product-of.html</a><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white;\"><b>Below: CHOOTIYA white men claimed that Kathakali skirts were copied from skirts of Portuguese women--what do they know --we are talking about 33 milliniums here . Below Theyyam skirt being made&nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-NzBcSM1rUYE/WOZSBnK9VeI/AAAAAAABSJs/vj5bCyV614solrUWbV_FPgAn3CfKhRLaQCLcB/s1600/theywwyam_photo_story_by_shyjith_kannur_06.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"426\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-NzBcSM1rUYE/WOZSBnK9VeI/AAAAAAABSJs/vj5bCyV614solrUWbV_FPgAn3CfKhRLaQCLcB/s640/theywwyam_photo_story_by_shyjith_kannur_06.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Kathakali never used wind instruments. But\nKoodiyattam used an amazing double reed Kuzhal.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Today this form of dance using Sanskrit verses\n100% is claimed by TAMIL PRIDE ( so what else is new ? ) <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-dVHs-H_9pbg/WOZQn_WTU7I/AAAAAAABSJc/lnAH_-PAiuEz9n-Dywk7nhrw7He7JxHSQCLcB/s1600/theyyffam59.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"478\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-dVHs-H_9pbg/WOZQn_WTU7I/AAAAAAABSJc/lnAH_-PAiuEz9n-Dywk7nhrw7He7JxHSQCLcB/s640/theyyffam59.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">It is officially recognised by UNESCO as a\nMasterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Jew Rothschild\u2019s agent Indian President\nSarvapalli Radhakrishnan converted Koodiyattam into Rothschild\u2019s play using all\nRothschild\u2019s FAKE DASA creations<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-1U9fDu-s_E8/WOZO-rmixII/AAAAAAABSJM/CRg31W8e-8YTnkhcTe1RXF39vaYzgtuxgCLcB/s1600/thddeyyam_photo_story_by_shyjith_kannur_16.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em;
