Leela: To imitate\nthe lover by voice and physical care. The famous example of Leela can be from\nRas Leela. In that, Radha imitates Lord Krishna and taking his flute dances the\ndance of Krishna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2. Vilasa: The sudden\nand beautiful change in the expressions of the body and voice as a result of\nmeeting with the loved ones is called Vilasa. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">3. Vichchitti: When\nthere is a great change by dress and Kanti is influenced thereby, it is called\nVichchitti. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4. Vibhrama: To wear a\ngarment of a particular portion of the body on a different part of body in\nhaste. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">5. Kilinkichita: To depict\nKrodha, Asru and Harsha together is Kilinkichita. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">6. Mottayita: To be\nmerged in the Bhava of the beloved when his name or something pertaining to him\nis mentioned. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">7. Kuttamita: To show\nfalse anger when the lover has come. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">8. Bibboka: To behave badly\nwith the lover even when Abhimana does not exist. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">9. Lalita: To arrange\nthe limbs and their movements gracefully. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">10. Vihrita: The Bhava\nof silence due to constraint even after meeting with the lover.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Natya Sastra gives&nbsp; information about; the Samgraha (collection)\nof everything like Rasas, Bhavas, Abhinaya (gesticulatory representation)\nDharmi (Rehearsed practice), Vrtti (Style), Pravrtti, (Action), Siddhi\n(Achievement), Svaras (notes), Atodya (instrumental music), Gana (song), and\nRanga (the stage), etc.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Thus, the Natya Sastra is not only conceptually\ndifferent but has also its unique definition of the theatreIn the modern world,\nall the concepts have gone to its minutest details i.e. from mini to micro\nlevels. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However, the Natya\nSastra is a torch light concept, which means that practically whatever required\nto do a good theatre is covered under the Natya Sastra. Literature, acting,\ndance, song, music, production and the theatre and stage are covered under this\nSastra. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unique features of the\nNatya Sastra are Dharmi (Rehearsed practice), Vrtti (Style), Pravrtti,\n(Action), Siddhi (Achievement). Thus, it suggests that not merely external\nrequirements but internal needs and intangible assets in this form too are\nrequired for theatre. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">That Samgraha in regard\nto the Natyaveda comprises of the Rasas, Bhavas, Abhinaya (Gesticulatory\nrepresentation) Dharmi (Rehearsed practive), Vrtti (Style), Pravrtti, (Action),\nSiddhi (Achievement), Svaras (notes), Atodya (instrumental music), Gana (song),\nand Ranga (the stage)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Natya Sastra\ndefines the character and the corresponding requirement for the level of\nperformance, the types of the characters, the different kind of people in the\nsociety and their strata and required understanding to develop and achieve it\nfor a performance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It shows the path and\nexplains about the content of theatre - Rasas, Bhavas, Abhinaya (gesticulatory\nrepresentation), Dharmi (Rehearsed practice), Vrtti (Style), Pravrtti,\n(Action), Siddhi (Achievement), Svaras (notes), Atodya (instrumental music),\nGana (song), and Ranga (the stage) <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to Natya\nShastra&nbsp; \u2018Natya Bavanu kirtanam\u2019.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In simple words, theatre is all about\nemotions<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Actors should be aware\nof body, voice, make-up, props and the gesture and postures of acting to enable\nthem express various temperaments.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are &nbsp;four types of Abhinaya, namely, (1) Angika,\n(2) Vacika, (3) Aharya and (4) Sattvika.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Angika \u2014 pertaining to\nthe body and its limbs \u2026 This involves the whole body of the actor and included\nan elaborate scheme of facial expression, mime, and gestures, accompanied by\ntheir appropriate movements, poses and attitudes. Hand gestures are another\nintegral part of Angika since the interpretation of the text is mainly conveyed\nthrough this. The holistic communication of the story is through the gestures,\nfacial expressions and body movements, the Angikabhinaya.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vachika \u2014 relating to\nthe vocal including proper pronunciation, modulation of voice accents and\npercussion\u2026 One of the distinguishing characteristics of Kathakali is that the\nactors do not speak. Vachika (drama text in the form of verses and songs) are\nrecited and sung by vocalists. These songs are explained and interpreted in\ndetails by actors through an elaborate method of angikabhinaya, which consists\nof highly codified gestures, facial expression, and body movements.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Satvika \u2014\nrepresentation of psychic condition \u2026 A highly stylized technique in the\ninvocation of bhava has been developed in Kathakali. This is called Rasabhinava.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Ahraya \u2014 costume, make-up, embellishments , ornaments , stage props etc<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vrttis \u2013 The Vrttis\n(Styles) are of four kinds (1) Bharati (Pertaining to the goddness of speech\n(verbal)], (2) Sattvati (The Grand one), (3) Kaisiki (the graceful one) and (4)\nthe Arabhati (the energetic or impetuous one).&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">.</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vyabhichari Bhavas:---<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">1 Swatantra Vishayaukta\nBhavas (Independent lustful )--Garva (Arrogance), Lajja (Vrida - Bashfulness),\nand Sentiments)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2 Manke Aaveg\n(Psyological forces)-- Avega (excitement), Amarsa (indignation), Avahittha\n(Dissimulation), Autsukya, (impatient, curosity) Trasa (fright), Harsha (joy)\nand Visada (Despair).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">3 Antaha karana Vritti\n(Internal Actions)-- Sanka (Suspicious), Smruti (recollection), Mati (self\nassurance), Vitarka, (deliberation) and Chinta (anxiety)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4 Mansik Avastha\n(Psychological Conditions)-- Dainya (Depression), Mada (Inebriation),\nJadata&nbsp; Stupefaction), Ugrata (Cruelty),\nMoha (delusion), Svapna (Dreaming), Alasya (lethargy), Unmaada, (madness)\nChapalata (in constancy), Nirveda (Despondency), Dhairya (patience) and Glani\n(Weakness).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">5 Sharirik Avasthas\nSrama (exhaustion),&nbsp;&nbsp; (Physical\nconditions)-- Apasmara (Loss of memory), Marana (death), Nidra (Sleep), Vibodha\n(Wakening), and Vyadhi (Sickness)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Category Vyabhichari\nBhava \u2013<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">1 Sukhatmak (Pleasures)\nGarva (Arrogance), Autsukya (impatient curiosity), Harsa (joy), Mada\n(Inebriation), Chapalata (in constancy), and Dhrti (Fortitude)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2 Dukhatmak (Painful)\nVrida (Bashfulness), Asuya (envy), Amarsa (Anger, Indignation) Avahittha\n(Dissimulation) Trasa (fright), Visada (Despair), Sanka (Suspicious) Cinta\n(anxiety) Ugrata (Ferocity, Cruelty) Moha (delusion), Alasya (lethargy), Unmada\n(madness), Glani (Weakness) Apasmara (Loss of memory) Marana (death) and Vyadhi\n(Sickness)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">3 Ubhayatmak (having\nboth qualities) Avega (excitement), Smriti (recollection) Dainya (Depression),\nJadata (Stupefaction) Svapna (Dreaming), and Chapalata (in constancy)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4 Udasin (Depressive)\nVitarka (deliberation), Mati (self assurance), Srama (exhaustion), Nidra\n(sleep) and Vibodh (Wakening).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vyabhichari Bhavas\naccording to Psychology --<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Category Vyabhichari\nBhava--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">1 Manovikara (Mental\nInclination) Nirveda (Despondency), Sanka (Suspicion), Harsa (joy), Dainya\n(Depression) (Depression), Ugrata (Ferocity, Cruelty), Chinta (Anxiety), Trasa\n(fright), Asuya (envy), Amarsa (Anger, Indignation) Garva (Arrogance),Vrida\n(Bashfulness), Avega (Excitement), Visada (Despair), and Autsukya (impatient\ncuriosity).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2 Amnovikaratmak\nAnubhutis (NonPsychological Inclinations) Dhrti (fortitude), Smrti\n(recollection), Mati (self assurance), and Tarka (Argument).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">3 Sharirik Samvedan\nAnubhava (Physically Sensitive Transitory) Apasmara (Loss of memory), Sram\n(Exhaustion), Glani (Weakness), Alasya (lethargy), and&nbsp; Vyadhi (Sickness)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4 Na Bhaav Na\nSmruti--&nbsp; (Neither Emotion nor\nExperience) Mada (Inebriation), Nidra (sleep), Supta (Sleeping, Dreaming),\nVibodha (Wakening), Marana (death), Avhittha (Dissimulation) Unmada (madness),\nJadata (Stupefication) Chapalata (in constancy) and Moha (delusion).</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Category Vyabhichari\nBhava --1 Sharirik Avastha--(Indicators of Physical conditions)--Glani\n(Weakness), Mada (Inebriation), Srama (Exhaustion), Alasya (lethargy), Jadata\n(Stupefication), Moha (delusion), Nidra (sleep), Supta (Dreaming), Apasmara\n(Loss of memory), Prabodh (Wakening), Vyadhi (Sickness), Unmada (madness) and Marana\n(death).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2 Bhavnaon ki\nTivrata--(Intensity of Feelings)-- Chapalata (in constancy), Aaveg (Excitement)\nUgrata (Ferocity, Cruelty).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">3 Prathmik Bhavna\n(Primary Feelings)-- Sanka (Suspicious), Amarsa (Anger and Indignation), Trasa\n(fright) and Garva (Arrogance).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4 Sammishra\nBhavna--(Mixed \u2013 Blended Feelings) Vrida (Bashfulness) and Asuya (envy).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">5 Jnyanamatak\nManovastha-- (Conscious mental conditions)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mati (self assurance),\nVitarka (deliberation), Avhittha (Dissimulation), Smrti (recollection) and Mati\n(self assurance).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">6 Sadhit Bhavna\n(Emotions which are conceived)- Autsukya (impatient curiosity), Dainya\n(Depression), Visada (Despair), Harsa (joy), Dhrti (fortitude), Chinta\n(anxiety), and Nirveda (Despondency)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Category Vyabhichari\nBhava-- -- (Transitory Emotions Parallel to Physical conditions)--1 Marana\n(death), Vyadhi (Sickness), Glani (Weakness) Srama (Exhaustion) Alasya\n(lethargy), Nidra (sleep), Svapna (Dreaming), Apasmara (Loss of memory), Unmada\n(madness), Mada (Inebriation), Moha (delusion), Jadata (Stupefication),\nChaplata (in consistency) and Prabodha (Wakening).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2 Jajatmak Manovastha-\n(Transitory Emotions Parallel to Intellectual conditions) --Smrti\n(recollection), Mati (self assurance) and Vitarka (deliberation)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">3 Bhavnatmak\nManovastha- Bhava (Transitory Emotions Parallel to Sentimental conditions)--\nHarsa (Joy), Avmarsa (Indignation), Dhrti (Fortitude), Ugrata (Ferocity,\nCruelty), Aveg (Excitement) Vishad (Despair), Nirveda (Despodency), Autsukya\n(impatient curiosity), Chnta (anxiety), Sanka (Suspicious) Asuya (envy), Trasa\n(fright), Garva (Arrogance), Dainya (Depression), Avhitha and Vrida\n(Bashfulness).</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Categories of\nVyabhichari Bhavas by (1) Vega \u2013 Force (2) Bhavna \u2013 Sentiment (Emotion)\n(3)&nbsp; sthittsthapakta \u2013Flexibility<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">1 Vegatmak Vyabhichari\nBhava (Forceful Transitory Emotions)-- Avega (Excitement), Chaplata (in&nbsp; consistency)-Asuya (envy), Amarsa (Loss of\nMemory), Ugrata (Ferocity, Cruelty), Mada (Inebriation), Unmada (madness), Glani\n(Weakness) Harsa (Joy), Trasa (fright), Marana (death).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2 Bhavnatmak\nVyabhichari Bhava (Sentimental Transitory Emotions)-- Autsukya (impatient\ncuriosity), Nirveda (Despondency), Cinta (anxiety), Visada (Despair), Moha\n(delusion) Vibodha (Wakening), Sanka (Suspicion), Vitarka (deliberation), Smrti\n(recollection), Mati (self assurance), and Garva (Arrogance)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">3 Sthittsthapak\nVyabhichari Bhava---(Flexible Transitory Emotions)-- Dhrti (Fortitude),\nDainya&nbsp; Depression), Alasya (lethargy),\nNidra (sleep), Svapna (Dreaming), Vrida (Bashfulness), Avhittha\n(Dissimulation), Jadata (Stupefication), Vyadhi (Sickness), Apasmara (Loss of\nmemory)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: large;\"><b>Below: There are BIRIYANI PACKET mourning rudaalis ( professional wailers ) who cry EXACTLY the same way if their contracted political leader dies --- or her dog dies,--- or her mother dies,--- or her neighbours lover dies, ---or her son dies ---or her friends sister dies --- or whatever&nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/LaDuEJ2Fehg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/LaDuEJ2Fehg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">IN INDIAN DANCE THERE IS --</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO SHOWING CAMEL TOE, &nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO ASSHOLE DOING PEEK A BOO BEHIND THONG , &nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO GYMNASTICS, &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO ACROBATICS, &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO ROTATING ON HEADS, &nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO TRAPEZE, &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO ROPE CLIMBING , &nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO TIP RIDICULOUS TOEING, &nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO WHIRLING AROUND A STUPID POLE , &nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO SOMERSAULTS , &nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO MORBID PELVIC THRUSTS,&nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">NO SOPRANO HOLLERING --&nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: x-large;\"><b>WE DANCE REAL !</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/q-smmT_Icdo/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/q-smmT_Icdo?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</span></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">My heart gasps -- it now\nquivers in fear -- &nbsp;dark ominous clouds\nroll overhead-- &nbsp;fear engulfs my heart --\ntears sometimes cascade from my eyes--, when I open my bag of memories and only\ndry leaves come out--&nbsp;&nbsp; your touch had\nonce made my dry branches green -- &nbsp;my\nmind that you peeked into, &nbsp;to whom can I\nshow it now, &nbsp;moon beams now scald my\nbody-- my body you touched in now shrouded, &nbsp;you are now out of my reach above, &nbsp;my wings are clipped, &nbsp;my heart gasps --<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Dil hoom hoom kare,\nghabraaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Ghan dham dham kare,\ndarr jaaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Ek boond kabhi paani ki\nmori ankhiyon se barsaaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dil hoom hoom kare,\nghabraaye</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Teri jhori daaroon, sab\nsukhe paat jo aaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Tera chhua laage, meri\nsukhi daar hariyaaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Dil hoom hoom kare,\nghabraaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Jis tan ko chhua tune,\nus tan ko chhupaaoon <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Jis man ko laage naina,\nvoh kisko dikhaaoon <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">O more chandrama, teri\nchaandni ang jalaaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Teri oonchi ataari\nmaine pankh liye katwaaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Dil hoom hoom kare,\nghabraaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Ghan dham dham kare,\ndarr jaaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Ek boond kabhi paani ki\nmori ankhiyon se barsaaye <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Dil hoom hoom kare,\nghabraaye</span></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">THE WHITE MAN CONVERTED OUR TEMPLE DANCERS TO WHORES</b><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/02/devadasi-system-immoral-lie-of-temple.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">&nbsp;http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/02/devadasi-system-immoral-lie-of-temple.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">THE DESCENDANTS OF THE SOMNATH TEMPLE DANCERS WERE KILLED BY\nJEW HITLER AND CROATIAN SADIST ANTE PAVELIC , AS SCUM GYPSIES .</b><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/11/the-sack-of-somnath-temple-by-mahmud-of.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/11/the-sack-of-somnath-temple-by-mahmud-of.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n</div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Abhinaya Darpan (a\ndescriptive primmer for dancers) mentions that the dancer should sing the song\nby the throat, express the meaning of the song through hand gestures, show the\nstate of feelings in the song by eyes, and express the rhythm with his or her\nfeet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">From the Natya Shastra,\na text on the arts, this beautiful quotation and translation is often quoted by\nIndian classical dance instructors:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Yato hastastato\ndrishtihi\"...\"Where the hand is, the eyes follow\"</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Yato drishtistato\nmanaha\"...\"Where the eyes go, the mind follows\"</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Yato manastato\nbhavaha\"...\"Where the mind is, there is the feeling\" Where the\nmind goes, the mood (bhava) follows,</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Yato bhavastato\nrasaha\"...\"Where there is feeling, there is mood/flavour, sweetness\n(i.e.,appreciation of art; aesthetic bliss)\" Where the mood goes, there\narises the sentiment<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So vast are the\nsubtleties expressed in the hand gestures of hasta that the vastness of what\nbeing human entails, and perhaps even what the entire universe contains, might\nbe expressed by the dancer<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hasta form a distinct\ncoded language which brings a unique poetic element while performing, so too\nwhen abhinaya (traditional facial expressions), pose (attitude), and rhythm\ncomplete the language, the dancer may express practically anything and\neverything to an attentive audience.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In appropriate ways,\nKathakali makes use of the Navarasas (nine moods) and their respective\nSthayibhavas (permanent states of mind) together with the Sancharibhava\n(transitory moods). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The actors' faces\nreflect their feelings distinctly, as does a mirror. This produces similar\nfeelings and emotions in the mind of the spectators.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are Thirty-three\nsuch Bhavas, dance expressions, as enumerated in the Shastras: ---<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">1.Nirveda (hates own\nself), 2. GIani (from tiresomeness), 3. Shanka, 4. Shrama 5. Dhrity (Santosh),\n6.Jarata (which arises on hearing any bad message of a beloved), 7.Harsha,\n8.Dainya, 9.Ougrya, 10.Chinta, 11. Trasa, 12. Asuya or Irsha (arising from\nsomebodys wealth), 13. Amarsha, 14. Garva, 15. Smriti, 16. Marana, 17. Mada,\n18. Supta (a particular situation at the time of lying down),19. Nidra, 20.\nVivodha (to be awakened or to awake), 21. Vrira (Lajja, bashfulness), 22.\nApasmar (lunaticism), 23. Moha, 24.Mati (the knowledge of things at their\nproper places), 25. Alasya, 26. Avega, 27.Tarka, 28. Avahitta, 29. Vyadhi, 30.\nUnmada,31.Vishada, 32. Autsukya, 33. Chapalya<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eight rasas and\nassociated bhavas are named and their enjoyment is likened to savoring a meal:\nrasa is the enjoyment of flavors that arise from the proper preparation of\ningredients and the quality of ingredients.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One ingredient in a\njuice (incidentally also called Rasa in Sanskrit) is not relish-able. However,\nby putting in herbs, spices and other ingredients, processing, blending,\ncamouflaging and properly preparing it, the juice can be made worthy of\npleasing and relishing.&nbsp; Thus all this\nprocess put together becomes the term \u2018Rasa\u2019.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0924\u0935</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0924\u092f\u0947</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u092a\u093f\u0924\u094b</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0930\u0938\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0930\u091c\u093e\u0902\u0938\u094d\u092f\u0928\u0941</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0935\u093f\u0937\u094d\u0920\u093f\u0924\u093e\u0903\u0964</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0926\u093f\u0935\u093f</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0935\u093e\u0924\u093e\u0907\u0935</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0936\u094d\u0930\u093f\u0924\u093e\u0903\u0965</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>(Rig Veda I.187.4) &nbsp;&nbsp;5000 BC<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Food has &nbsp;six kinds of Rasa or taste which food has --but\nwhich all tastes cannot be found in one place or item, for these tastes are\nvariously distributed throughout space. Food, in this context, means matter or\nobjects or thoughts, which are all produced effects, effects that are produced\nowing to various causes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Rasas are the unique qualities which bring about\nvariety in things created whose source is one and one only<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The rule that the old\nmasters of the Kathakali teach their pupils says: where their hands are to\nrepresent an action, there must be the eyes; Where the eyes go, there must\nfollow the intellect, and the action represented by the hands must give rise to\na definite feeling which is reflected on the face of the actor .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">From this rule it\nfollows that the face is an emotional mirror whose reactions are conditioned\nnot by the actions of another actor, but by the story described by the hands of\nthe actor himself.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is a&nbsp; a double structure in the acting of the\nactor; The latter must, more or less simultaneously, engage different\npsycho-physical and technical means to represent two complementary aspects of a\nhistory, the purely \"narrative\" aspect (the hands) communicating what\nhas just happened in a particular episode, and the emotional aspect (the face)\nconstituting the subjective reactions of the personage to the situation in\nwhich it is located. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The head is the\ncharacter and that the body is the phenomenological world.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Check out the dance of\nShiva Nataraja. The whole body of God is the world with its dialectical cosmic\nprocess of creation and destruction (the legs create and the hands destroy),\nwhile the face reveals the personal attitude of the Godhead in its expression\nof serenity and bliss.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mudras , gestures with well-designed meaning composed by\nhands and fingers, are veritable visual ideograms that replace speech.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There 24 fundamental mudras\nwhich, in Kathakali , according to the various possible combinations of them, and\n&nbsp;in relation to the movements of the body\nand the mimicry of the face, can express more than &nbsp;three thousand words .. Each word in the piece\nis expressed by a mudra , even grammatical themes such as \"if\",\n\"when\", \"but\".<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Kathakali actor\ngives free rein to his fantasy and his imagination.&nbsp;&nbsp; Suppose he describes a woman. &nbsp; After\ncomposing the mudra corresponding to this word, he begins to elaborate the\n\"beauty\" of the woman by introducing attributes or metaphors such as\n\"beautiful as the lotus\", \"tender as a rose petal\",\n\"with eyebrows Like waves \".&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Kathakali actor is graded by his own imaginative faculty and this\ntalent for improvisation - manodharma -&nbsp;&nbsp;\nindispensable qualities for an actor.&nbsp;\nIt is NOT right to say that Kathakali is a rigid science.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In reality, the actor is a sculptor whose\nbody is simultaneously chisel and block of marble. It takes some intelligence\nto understand this. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 16px;\">A mountain is not simply a gesture. Its altitude can be read in the eyes of the Kathakali actor, in his gaze, while we see the body climb this mountain, the body which is simultaneously mountain and mountaineer.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 16px;\">&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">This dialectic of the\ngame allows the viewer to judge the exterior as interior, to be introduced into\nthe internal mechanism and to apprehend it as a totality.&nbsp; &nbsp;In his\ngame, the actor arrives at a continual superposition between the subject and\nthe object, between the world of subjective emotions and the phenomenological\nworld, between action and reaction. &nbsp;Till today no white man has really understood Kathakali at a deep level.&nbsp;</span></span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mudras are not only a\nvisual ideogram of descriptive value, but constitute a process of emotional\nplastic representation that engages the actor's body in the empty space he\nfills with his presence and dynamics.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The expression of each\nword of the play by a mudra can be regarded as the cause of the long duration\nof a Kathakali show. A play, which takes only twenty minutes, presented in this\nway on the stage, can last more than &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">four consecutive hours with the audience\ntransfixed.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Of properties,&nbsp; the Kathakali stage can become a palace or\nforest at a moment\u2019s notice. The actor\u2019s physicalisation of dramatic action and\nof the rich poetic images of the text , supplemented by his dancing of set pieces\nof choreography provoke the audience\u2019s imaginative engagement in the creation\nof the \u2018world\u2019 of the play Kathakali dance ranges from the very strong and\nvigorous (tandava) to the soft or languid (lasya)..</span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">For abhinaya, there are\nfour separate and fully developed styles are adopted. They are Aharya\n(costumes), Vachika (literary text), Angika (gestrual) and Satvika (emotional).</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The white man used to\nwatching his own SHALLOW mindless theatre &nbsp;will wonder how people in Kerala sit from dawn\nto dusk watching Kathakali. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is because we have a completely different\napproach to theater. We judge the skill and virtuosity of the actor. Each\ngesture, movement and expression of the actor is valued and evaluated by a\npublic of connoisseurs who does not hesitate to show loudly his appreciation or\nhis spite.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A pretender Kathakali dancer will not last more than a single show . This is why the\ntraining is long ( minimum 4 years with just meal breaks and 8 hours sleep ) and\nrigid.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to the Natya\nshastra, the goals of theatre is to empower aesthetic experience, deliver\nemotional rasa. Entertainment is an effect, but not the primary goal of Kathakali.\nThe primary goal is to create rasa so as to lift and transport the spectators,\nunto the expression of ultimate reality and transcendent values.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The success of a\nperformance art is measured not by the reviews, awards or recognition the\nproduction receives, but only when it is performed with skilled precision,\ndevoted faith and pure concentration such that the artist gets the audience\nemotionally absorbed into the art and immerses the spectator with pure joy of\nrasa experience<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Tl3UKV1z9lM/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Tl3UKV1z9lM?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rasa is the invisible\nsubstance that gives life meaning.&nbsp; Rasa is\nalso described&nbsp; as the state of ecstasy\nin the union with divine&nbsp; . According to\nNatya shastra, a rasa is a synthetic phenomenon and the goal of any creative\nperformance art, oratory, painting or literature.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rasa may be said to be the\noriginal emotion transfigured by aesthetic delight, one way is through the use\nof gestures and facial expressions of the actors. Expressing Rasa in classical\nIndian dance form is referred to as Rasa-abhinaya.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rasa, the dominant emotion,\naroused by a Kathakali recital , is&nbsp;\ntasted by the audience, --it has a different quality from that which is\naroused in real life. Rasas are created by bhavas. Rasa is about what the mind\nfeels and the expression of the feeling thereafter.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While mudras form the\nalphabet, a movement (chulippu) accompanies each mudra to constitute the\ngrammar to which navarasa is added. Sringara is considered as the king of\nrasas. There are sambhoga sringara and vipralambha sringara. Sambhoga sringara\nis the love in union and viprlambha sringara as the love in seperation.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hasya\nis not laughter but humour created using either a situation or a mode of\nbehaviour. The bhava of divine peacefulness is shanta. Natyasastra does not\nconsider shanta as a rasa<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are usually\ndifferent facial expressions like thadam ilakkal, purikam ilakkal, kannu\nsadhakam, netti ilakkal, kazhuthilakkal etc. Thadam ilakkal is the movement of\nlower part of the eyes. It is moved to show anger or sudden movements.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purikam\nilakkal means the movement of eyebrows. For showing rasa the movement of eye\nbrows is important. Kannu sadhakam is the practice of moving eyes to all\ndirections. Netti ilakkal is also an expression to show surprise or wonder. The\nfacial expressions are the locution of narratives. It is through this the\nnarrative is conveyed to the audience.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Kathakali, narration\nadvances through various techniques to catch the span of attention of audience.\nHere the non-literary elements are communicated through various techniques\napart from the linguistic richness. The stories are not narrated directly.\nThere is a need of making it strange to attract the audience.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are 2 kinds\nof narration \u2013 Primary and Embedded. Primary narrative comes first and embedded\nis the hidden one. A visual performance makes use of both the narratives in\nwhich the story comes as primary narrative whereas the techniques form an\nembedded narrative.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Usually the sloka will\nbe Sanskrit and the padam which follows this will be in manipravalam which is\nthe combination of Sanskrit and Malayalam. The use of space is an impetus to\nthe actor. He changes the place by revolving on the stage. Adidikkida is used\nto show the journey of the character. The technique of creating something from\nnothing is also a theatrical technique.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The nature of a\ncharacter plays a major role in spinning a story around it. The gradual\ndevelopment of emotions replaced the importance of plot in the repertoire.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is a traditional concept of narration\nin which the binary opposites play a relevant role in shaping a story-- the\nevents travel from the present to past and then again to the present.&nbsp; Equilibrium \u2013 disequilibrium \u2013 equilibrium<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is a conscious\neffort on the part of the creators of the Kathakali to avoid any form of\nexpression that traces or imitates the reality of everyday life.&nbsp; The make-up blurs the individual physiognomy\nof the actor to transform it into a supernatural face, into a suggestive mask.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The costumes completely break the organic harmony of the body and the new\nsilhouette that emerges strikes us by its architectonic and extraordinary\nproportions.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The play, mudras as\nwell as mimic of the face, uses a language where the reality is not illustrated\npassively, but recreated by original artistic means. The process distorts the\nactor's dynamic, without hindering it.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The actor always has his legs bent,\nknees apart, and he leans on the outer edges of the feet, an extremely fatiguing\nand painful position, the mastery of which is acquired only after a long\ntraining.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The actor follows his\nhands with his eyes all the time, he looks at them as if his hands become the\nobject or the person they want to present.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The extreme mobility of the hands\nand fingers touches us with an expressiveness that goes beyond all imagination.\nIt is especially the rapidity of these members and their compositions that\nfascinate, strange alphabet of deaf mutes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They are the matrix of epic\nmaterials that the actor represents and develops through its dynamics. The\nmovements of the various parts of the body are often based on a\ndesynchronization, on a clear divorce of the rhythm between the different\nlimbs.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The legs can move at an extraordinary speed while the hands sculpt the\nmudras with a slow and calculated precision. Or, facial expression can be\nlively and bodily actions impregnated with an austere and serene gravity. Kathakali\ndoes NOT use women.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Men play the\nrole.&nbsp; There is too much hardship while\ntraining for several years in the preteen years and women cannot survive this\nrigor.&nbsp; The approach, the mimicry, the\ngesticulation and the slightest movements of these actors reveal a deep\nknowledge of the psychology and the behavior of the woman.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is nothing\nvulgar or equivocal, no concession to what might flatter the taste of a popular\npublic. Playing such a role requires a skill that is a real test bed for the classical\nactor.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The style of singing\nparticular to Kathakali is called Sopana sangeetham (Sopana Music). Of the two\nsingers, the first singer (pinnani) keeps the steady beat of the thala\n(rhythmic pattern) by using the chengila (gongs), made of bell metal.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Music as\na vachika element in Kathakali is designed entirely to enable and enhance\ncharacterisation, and not primarily for expressing classical virtuosity. Also\nthe singer has to keep his eyes riveted on the actor for every little body\nmovement has to synchronise with the gong beat.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So adept are experienced\nsingers that every nuance of a moving facial muscle is anticipated and\nsynchronised with the gong rhythm. The training of a singer for Kathakali is in\nconjunction with a performing actor..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The singer has to control the\nperformance, its tempo and also the percussionists by his acute sense of\ntiming. The raga used is entirely governed by the mood and character.
